Award.AwardTitle: Linking Foraging Behaviors to Demography to understand Albatrosses Population Responses to Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the ecological consequences - present and future-of climate change is a central question in conservation biology. The goal of this project is to identify the effects of climate change on the Black-Browed Albatross, a seabird breeding in the Southern Ocean. The Black-Browed Albatross exhibits remarkable flight adaptations, using winds as an energy source to glide for long distances. This is the basis of their foraging strategy, by which they obtain food for themselves and their offspring. Climate change, however, is expected to modify wind patterns over the Southern Ocean. This project will analyze the effect of winds on life history traits (foraging behaviors, body conditions and demographic traits), and the effects of these traits on populations. New demographic models will provide the link between foraging behavior and the physical environment, and evaluate the persistence of this population in the face of climate change.

Understanding and predicting population responses to climate change is important because the world?s climate will continue to change throughout the 21st century and beyond. To help guide conservation strategies and policy decisions in the face of climate change, reliable assessments of population extinction risks are urgently needed. The Black-Browed Albatross is considered endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature due to recent drastic reductions in its population size. This project will improve our understanding of the mechanisms by which climate affects the life history and populations of Black-Browed Albatross to improve prediction of extinction risks under future climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ecological impacts of climate change are broad and diverse.  The goal of this project was to identify pathways by which climate change affect the life history traits of individuals, hence population dynamics for the Black-Browed Albatross, a seabird that breeds in the Southern Ocean.

 

Black-Browed Albatrosses spend half of the year at sea, between breeding seasons, and travels massive distances over the Southern Ocean in search of their preferred food: fish, squid and krill. The young birds remain at sea for nine years on average before they return to land, for the first time, to breed. Climate change is expected to modify sea surface temperature over the Southern Ocean, which will impact their food availability.

 

The birds were fitted with tiny geolocators that record light levels and immersion from which their location and foraging activity can be estimated. These birds are part of a population that has been surveyed for more than 35 years; hence researchers know the lifetime history of each individual (i.e. whether or not they survived, bred and raised successfully offspring). This project analyzed the effect of climate on life history traits (foraging behaviors, migratory schedule, body size and demographic traits), and the effects of these traits on populations. The team developed new demographic models providing the link between population, life history traits and sea surface temperatures.

 

The team found that adults change their date of return to the pre-breeding grounds rather than modifying their at-sea foraging activity when winter climate conditions vary, with very little effect on the population dynamic. Variation in sea surface temperature during late winter causes the biggest change in the population dynamic, because sea surface temperatures impact the survival of young.  Changes in sea surface temperature during the breeding season have little effect on the population dynamic. This result has important implications as the non-breeding season and young phase of the life cycle are two overlooked periods in seabird ecology because birds are at sea and thus difficult to observe. The advancement of new technology, such as geolocators, and long-term demographic studies, now allow unique insight to these mysterious phases of the life cycle that have the biggest effect on the persistence of the population.

 

Furthermore, bird foraging activity during the pre-breeding period has the largest impact on population dynamic among traits. This is the first study to establish the link between individual foraging behaviors and population dynamics, through their effect on demographic rates. This link is critically important for the persistence of Black-Browed Albatrosses because a population of individuals with the optimal traits (large structural size and intense foraging activity) could buffer the negative impact of unfavorable climate conditions.

 

In sum, this project has substantially improved our understanding of how climate influences life history traits and population dynamics of a seabird. This project has generated both methodological advances, in terms of new approaches for modeling the links between foraging behaviors and populations, and new scientific understanding of these mechanistic links, by which climate affects population.
